importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of publication of the article highlights a current global concern about extreme weather and the urgent need for early-warning systems in the context of escalating climate-related disasters.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article emphasizes that 2025 has seen numerous extreme weather events, such as floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, illustrating the immediacy and severity of the climate crisis.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reports that over 2 million people have died due to weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.

While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52 in the past decade), half of 62 assessed countries have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone contexts.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action, and the WMO’s goal is to not only warn the world but to empower it.
Climate change is causing more frequent and intense extreme weather events, as seen in 2025 with floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US.

The collapse of a Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025, predicted through monitoring, allowed evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the value of real-time monitoring and early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has called for urgent global expansion of early-warning systems for extreme weather events, emphasizing that nearly half of all countries lack adequate systems, especially in developing nations. Over the past 50 years, more than 2 million people have died due to climate-related disasters, with 90% of fatalities occurring in developing countries. Despite progress in early-warning adoption—rising from 52 to 108 countries in a decade—the assessment of 62 countries shows that half have only basic capacity and 16% have less. The article highlights real-world examples such as the 2025 flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, as well as the successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten due to a predicted glacier collapse. The WMO stresses that early warnings lead to early action, and that climate change is making weather events more extreme, making early-warning systems vital for saving lives and protecting infrastructure globally.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
